title: 111_hr993
content: The "Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Act of 2009" establishes a Commission to examine land claims, provide assistance, and report findings. It includes definitions, membership details, miscellaneous powers, and authorization of appropriations. The "Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Act of 2009" defines key terms such as Commission, Treaty of Guadalupe-Hidalgo, and eligible descendant for the purpose of examining land claims and providing assistance. The "Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Act of 2009" defines terms like community land grant as land held in common by families under a grant from Spain or Mexico before specific dates, and reconstituted as a municipality with proper rights. The "Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Act of 2009" recognizes the unique history of land ownership in the western and southwestern United States due to Spanish and Mexican land grants. Congress finds that certain provisions of the Treaty of Guadalupe-Hidalgo have not been fully implemented, leading to questions about land ownership in these regions. Certain public lands in western and southwestern States still exist, and Congress has used land claim commissions in the past to examine disputed land possession questions successfully. Establishment of the Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Commission with seven members appointed by the President, including eligible descendants and a member of an Indian tribe. Members serve for the life of the Commission and receive compensation at the Executive Schedule level V. SEC. 4. EXAMINATION OF LAND CLAIMS. The Commission allows eligible descendants to file a petition seeking validation of a community land grant claim. The petition must be submitted within five years of the enactment of the Act and include names, addresses of petitioners, and proof of the land being a community grant at the time of the Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty. The Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty requires petitioners to provide details of the community land grant, including a survey or sketch map, residency or intent to settle on the land, and all known facts and relevant documents. The Commission holds hearings for all interested parties, and has the power to issue subpoenas. The Commission has the power to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to petitions submitted under the Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty. Failure to comply may result in a court order for testimony or evidence, with penalties for contempt. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to petitions under the Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty. Subpoenas must be served in accordance with the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Process for court applications can be served in the person's judicial district. The Commission will determine the validity of community land grants based on submitted petitions, hearings, and relevant information. Recommended relief may be provided in response to a petition. The Commission, in response to valid petitions, will recommend appropriate relief, including the reconstitution of community land grants. The decision on petition validity will not impact non-Federal land ownership rights. Recommendations for reconstituting land grants will only apply to Federal lands. The Commission will modify recommendations for reconstitution of community land grants by substituting comparable Federal lands in the same State as non-Federal lands. The Commission will establish a Community Land Grant Study Center in New Mexico to conduct research and investigations. The Comptroller General may provide assistance with personnel and resources from the Government Accountability Office. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, and accept gifts for its work. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can use the United States mails. The Commission, as an agency of the United States, can request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission is also granted immunity under part V of title 18, United States Code. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress after making decisions, including recommendations on community land grants. The Commission will terminate 180 days after submitting its final report. $1,900,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2010-2016 for Commission activities and the Community Land Grant Study Center.
